title: 103_hr4759
content: The "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994" aims to enhance mathematics and science education by leveraging the Department of Energy's capabilities and fostering collaboration between federal agencies and the education community. Recognizing the value of outstanding elementary and secondary school teachers, the Act proposes a program where these educators can contribute their expertise to education programs in government roles. The Act aims to establish a national fellowship program for exceptional math and science teachers, who will be known as "Albert Einstein Fellows". The Act defines key terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit organization administering the fellowship program, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" for math or science teachers with specific achievements. The Act defines key terms related to the fellowship program, including "secondary school" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Teachers must meet specific criteria to participate in the program, such as receiving national or State recognition and taking a sabbatical leave from teaching. The Fellowship Program is authorized under Section 5 of the Act. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program allows the Secretary to provide fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers. The number of fellowships awarded may be reduced based on funding availability, with priority given to selected individuals. The Secretary shall provide fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers in various government departments and agencies for a 10-month period coinciding with the academic year. The Secretary awards fellowships to exceptional math or science teachers for 10 months, aligning with the academic year. A contractor administers the Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program, including managing the application process and screening applicants. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects 10 outstanding math and science teachers, administers the selection process, provides orientation, establishes evaluation programs, submits annual reports to the Secretary, and manages all funds received. The contractor for the Einstein Fellowship Program administers all funds received for fellowship recipient salaries, administrative expenses, orientation programs, relocation expenses, and final selection interviews. The contractor for the Einstein Fellowship Program administers funds for fellowship recipient salaries, administrative expenses, orientation programs, relocation expenses, and final selection interviews. Fellowship recipients may be reimbursed for travel and professional meetings from non-Federal sources. The contractor invites semifinalists to Washington, D.C., for interviews after an initial screening process, with final selections announced before May 1 each year. The Speaker and Minority Leader of the House of Representatives are involved in the final selection process. The selection process for the Einstein Fellowship Program involves various leaders choosing fellowship recipients for placement in the House of Representatives, Senate, and various government departments. Each individual selected for the fellowship program will be placed within the department, agency, institute, or office they administer. Final placement involves interviewing in different sections before being placed on or before the first day of the fellowship period. SEC. 6. Fellowship recipients will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-13 of the General Schedule. SEC. 7. $550,000 authorized for fiscal year 1995, with additional funds for 1996-2001 to implement the Act.
